quote: Peldor joi, Emissary.
Peldor joi to you.
Looks like the festival was a   success.
Everyone seemed to enjoy it.        Thank you, captain.
For what?
For insisting that the festival    take place in spite of the fact    that we're in the middle of a    war.
War or no war -- we have a lot    to be grateful for. It's    important to remember that.
Yes, it is.        Shouldn't you be heading over to    the wardroom for the ceremony?
I'm on my way.
Nerys -- I've been looking for    you.
I don't really feel like talking    to you right now.
Don't you want to hear my side    of the story?
No.
Somebody has to maintain order    on the Promenade.

I'd hardly call it an arrest --   he wasn't in the holding cell    for more than an hour. Besides,    he was breaking the law.     Fundraising on the Promenade    without a license is strictly    forbidden. Station regulation    fifteen-twenty-six, paragraph    seven--
Vedek Solis was collecting    donations for Bajoran flood    victims!
A very worthy cause.    Nevertheless, station    regulations are quite clear --
I don't care about station    regulations.
Is that the Orb of Contemplation?
Good-bye, Odo.

... to Captain Benjamin Lafayette    Sisko, in recognition of your    remarkable leadership and    meritorious conduct against the    enemy, and in particular for    acts of personal bravery    displayed during the battle to    retake Deep Space Nine,    Starfleet Command is proud to    award you the Christopher Pike    Medal of Valor.
Congratulations, Ben.
Thank you, admiral.
(with a twinkle in     her eyes)    And to think... I knew him when    he was just a callow youth.
I bet even then he showed signs    of greatness.
Only with the ladies.
I'd like to hear more about    that.
Then let him tell you.
But he'll leave out all the good    parts.

The medal usually comes with a    lot more pomp and ceremony, but    we figured you wouldn't want to    be called back to Earth just to    sit through a bad chicken dinner    with a bunch of brass hats.
This suits me fine, admiral.
Now you have something else to    put on your desk besides that    baseball.
What she means to say, captain,    is that she can't think of    anyone more deserving of this    honor.
I certainly can't.
I'm proud of you, Dad.
If you'd excuse us, I'd like a    word with Captain Sisko.

I've got good news for you,    captain. Starfleet Command has    decided we've been waging a    defensive war long enough. They    figure we're never going to win    this thing unless we take the    fight into Dominion territory.
I know, you've been saying that    ever since the Romulans opened a    second front against the    Dominion. It took a while, but    your message finally got    through.
When do we go?
That all depends on you.
Me?
That's right, Ben. Starfleet    has chosen you to plan the    invasion of Cardassia.
Finally.
I've been waiting for you to get    out of that holosuite for twenty    minutes.
Sorry, Julian. We lost track of    the time.
Doing what? You were supposed    to be in there exercising. I    don't see any sweat. Where are    the bruises? The broken bones?    The blood?
We were... talking.
For an hour and forty-five    minutes?
It's a private matter.
We're thinking about having a baby.
It was a private matter.
Sisko to Commander Worf. Please    report to my office immediately.
Acknowledged.
You're both awfully quiet.
I don't want to dampen your    spirits, but I told you before    you got married that, medically    speaking, it wouldn't be easy    for a Trill and a Klingon to    have a child.
And I'm worried the kid will end    up looking like his father.
I hope she does.
A baby?
It's bad enough she married that    Klingon psychopath.
A baby... you know what this    means, don't you?
Their marriage is going to last    longer than we thought.
What about the Torg'Q system?    Of all the targets along the    border, it's the closest to    Cardassia Prime.
It's also the most heavily    fortified.
True.        But that could work to our    advantage. The Dominion will    never expect us to attack there.
The element of surprise might    give us an initial advantage...    but I'm not sure how long it    would last. And I don't even    want to think about our casualty    figures...
I recommend the Ventani System.    I know it's a long way from    Cardassia Prime, but its second    planet was the birthplace of    Tret Akleen -- the father of the    Cardassian Empire.
To lose such sacred ground would    be devastating to Cardassians    everywhere. And a great    propaganda victory for you.
Even so, there is little    strategic value in holding the    Ventani System.
And its loss would have no    effect on the Jem'Hadar.
True.
Something on your mind, Chief?
What about the Chin'toka System,    sir?
The Chin'toka System is    protected by a fleet of Dominion    ships.
The last time we patrolled that    section of the border, I noticed    something strange about the warp    signatures of their bigger    ships... the cruisers, the    destroyers...
Go on.
They were slightly different    from the first time we scanned    them. The field variance    readings seemed almost too    synchronized.
Are you suggesting that the warp    signatures are fake? That those    ships are no longer there?
It's possible.
Why would the Dominion pull so    many of their ships away from    the border?
Perhaps they've been sent to the    Romulan front.
Then how many ships does the    Dominion have at Chin'toka?
Five squadrons of Jem'Hadar    attack ships.
At the moment, that's the entire    Dominion "fleet" protecting the    Chin'toka System.
Only five squadrons... It    appears you've found the weak    spot we've been looking for.
Now all we have to do is    convince the Romulans to join    us.
That won't be an easy task.    They're an arrogant and    untrustworthy people.
Without their help, we'd have    little chance of success.
We will succeed. Mark my words.    By this time next year, the    three of us will drink bloodwine    in the halls of Cardassia's    Central Command.
You're worrying about nothing.
Am I? It's a mistake to    underestimate our enemy, Damar.    You're spreading our forces too    thinly.

Until we can find a way to bring    reinforcements from the Gamma    Quadrant, we have to make due    with what we have. Besides, you   told me we needed more ships on    the Romulan front. So I sent    them.
And in doing so, you left the    Chin'toka System vulnerable.
Not as vulnerable as you think.
You see, we don't need starships    to protect Chin'toka. Not anymore.
These are our new unmanned    orbital weapon platforms. Their    hulls are protected by    regenerative forcefields and    their arsenals include a    thousand plasma torpedoes.
I like them.
I thought you would. Which is    why I've already ordered their    deployment.
Legate Damar, excuse the    interruption but we have a...    problem.
What kind of problem?
Me.
Isn't anyone going to welcome me    home?
Heroes get welcomed home, Dukat.    Not failures. Or have you    forgotten that under your    leadership the Dominion almost    lost this war?
As I recall, you were right by    my side, agreeing with every one    of my decisions.
If you're here because of what    happened to your daughter --

You disappoint me, Damar. I    thought you, of all people,    would be glad to see your old    mentor.        Besides, I don't hold you    responsible for Ziyal's death.    You may have fired the phaser,    but it was Benjamin Sisko who    forced your hand. And that's    why I'm here.
The time has come for me to take   my revenge against the good   captain.

We're in the middle of a life-   and-death struggle for control   of the entire Alpha Quadrant,   and all you care about is   quenching your petty thirst for   revenge.       You haven't changed a bit, have   you?

On the contrary, I'm a new man.   I no longer have a need for   conquest or power. I've moved   beyond all that... I exist in a   state of perfect clarity. A   clarity I intend to share with   the universe.

You're right, Dukat. You have    changed. You've gone from being    a self-important egotist to a    self-deluded madman. I hardly    call that an improvement.        I don't have time for this.    Remove him.
Wait.        Why did you come here?
Isn't that obvious?
To give you what you desire    above all else. The Alpha    Quadrant.
All I need is a certain Bajoran    artifact... one of the many that    the Cardassians "appropriated"    during the occupation.
And how is this artifact going    to help us?
Let's just say it will make it    possible for Dominion    reinforcements to come through    the wormhole and destroy Captain   Sisko and the Federation once    and for all.
(to Sisko, re:     Martok)    Really, Captain, I see no reason    why I should sit here while this    Klingon jackal calls me a    coward.
Apparently, this "jackal" has    more courage than the entire    Romulan Senate.
You see my point?
General, you must try to remain    calm.
Calm? This is'no time for calm --        -- it's time to strike the    enemy, strike them hard.
We found their weak point. Now   we need to exploit it.
(to Sisko, re:    Letant)   But this p'tagh would rather sit   home and count his dead.
If we invade Cardassia now, all    we'll do is count our dead.
Gentlemen, please. We're    allies, remember that.
What good is an ally that'll    stab you in the back?
Notice the primitive rage in his    eye... the uncontrolled    brutality. Klingons can be    quite entertaining, don't you    agree? I think every Romulan    zoo should have a pair.
Sit down, general. Save your    anger for the Dominion.
Senator -- you've studied our    invasion plans...
I have. And I remain convinced    they're premature. Let the    Dominion continue to send their    fleets against us. We will    annihilate them one by one.
And they'll continue to rebuild    their ships and send more.
The Dominion breed Jem'Hadar    faster than we can destroy them.

The only way to achieve lasting    victory is to demolish their    shipyards, their weapon    plants... to force them to    retreat, deeper and deeper into    their own territory until our    ships surround their    headquarters on Cardassia Prime    and they have no choice but to    surrender. I know it won't be    easy... I know we'll pay a heavy    price for every system we take    from them. But, in the end,    it's the only way to drive the    Dominion out of the Alpha    Quadrant. And that's a goal we    all share. Klingons, Humans    and Romulans.
What am I going to do? Nerys    hates me.
I envy you. At least hate is an    emotion. All I get from Jadzia    is indifference.
Me, too.
For one brief moment, I was the    happiest man in the universe.    Now... it's over. I'll never be    happy again.
I know what you mean.
Me, too.
What am I going to do without    her?
(still thinking of     Dax)    I wish I knew.
Me, too.
I guess there's nothing else to    do but go back to work.
Good idea.
I think we cheered him up.
Me, too.        I wish there was someone to    cheer us up.
I know just the person.
That was great, VIC.
It's not exactly the most    requested song in my repertoire,    but I'm glad you liked it. So    why the long face, pallie?
It's a long story.
This wouldn't be about Dax's    baby, would it?
What is he, a telepath?
No, I'm a hologram.
A very smart hologram.

It's simple. You take one    beautiful, happily married    filly... add the possibility of    her giving birth to a foal, and    what does it leave you?    (not waiting for an    answer)   A couple of lovesick stallions   that never got out of the   starting gate.
You have any idea what he's    talking about?
I've got news for you two --    it's time to move onto greener    pastures.
It's not easy to lose a woman    like Dax.
I hate to break it to you,    pallie, but you lost her a long    time ago. You both did.
But lucky for you, space is big.    There are a lot of other nice    girls out there... with and    without spots. Capice?
That's it? That's supposed to    cheer us up?
The truth shall set you free.
Do you feel better?
A little. How about you?
I guess.
Good. Because you were starting    to depress the band.
Thanks, Vic. We appreciate the    advice.
(looking around the     room)    I like this place. I may have    to drop by more often.
Anytime, pallie, anytime.
Nice guys. But absolutely    clueless.
What do you think?
I think the Romulans have agreed    to invade Cardassia.
How'd you know?
The jambalaya's perfect.        When you're frustrated about    something you usually overcook    the rice.
You never told me that before.
I'm telling you now. So when do    we leave?
We?
I'm a journalist, Dad.    Remember?
Forget it, Jake. You're not    going.
But, Dad -- we're talking about    the invasion of Cardassia. A    savage thrust into the very    heart of the Dominion.         That's not how I would write it.
That's a relief, but you're    still not going.
I have to go. It's my job. Now    if you don't want me on the    Defiant, fine. I'll go with    General Martok -- get the story   from a Klingon perspective...
All right. The Defiant it is.
So when do we leave?
Just keep your bags packed.
Yes, sir.
Where are you going?
To pack my bags.
Do I have to remind you about    the need for strict security?
You just did.
What about your dinner?
It's delicious.
Jake.
Don't worry, Dad. We'll look   out for each other.
The Sisko is of Bajor.
It is where he belongs.
It is where he is meant to be.
Are you telling me not to go to   Cardassia?
You are the Sisko.
The Sisko is of Bajor.
It is dangerous to walk a    different path.
Dangerous? In what way?
The Sisko must not leave the    chosen path.
The Sisko is of Bajor.
It is where he belongs.
But why is it dangerous for me    to leave? Does it have    something to do with Bajor? You    have to tell me --
The Cardassians call them    orbital weapon platforms.
Intelligence reports indicate    that the Dominion is placing    hundreds of them throughout the    Chin'toka System.
Are they operational?
Not yet.
How much time do we have before    they are?
Two, maybe three days.
It would appear that your "weak    spot" is about to get a lot    stronger.
Leave it to a Romulan to run at    the first sign of trouble.

And leave it to a Klingon to    leap to the wrong conclusion.        The Romulan Empire has agreed to    join the invasion of Cardassia    and we live up to our    agreements. The question is:    can we launch an invasion before    their defensive grid is activated?
We'll have to leave first thing    in the morning.
Then it's settled. Good luck,    General.        Good luck to us all.
Romulans don't believe in luck.
All the better. That leaves    more for the rest of us.
You've been quiet, Ben. Those    weapon platforms have you    worried?
It's not that, sir.       It's about the Prophets -- the    wormhole aliens. They spoke to    me last night.
I hope they gave the mission    their blessing.
They told me not to go to    Cardassia -- that I should stay    here.
Did they give a reason?
Nothing concrete. Just that it    would be dangekous.
In what way? Dangerous to you?    To the mission? To Bajor?
I'm not sure.
(cutting to the    chase)   Then what are you telling me,   Ben? You want permission to   stay behind?
It's not about what I want.    It's about what the Prophets    want.
That's not a good enough answer.    Not from a Starfleet captain.
The Prophets don't see me as a    Starfleet Captain -- they see me    as their Emissary.

That's the problem, isn't it?    For the past six years, you've    tried to be both. And up to    now, I've been patient... I've    indulged you... I've gone out    on a limb for you many times.    But this is it. You have to    make a decision. You're either    the Emissary or a Starfleet    captain -- you can't be both.
I'll be on the Bridge of the    Defiant at oh-five hundred.
Good.
A combined fleet at Deep Space Nine?
Composed of Federation, Klingon    and Romulan ships!
You think they'll head for the    Chin'toka System?
I would.
Then we have nothing to worry    about. The Weapon Platforms    will be operational in time to    greet them.
That's a very comforting    thought... if it's accurate.
I'll make sure it is.
Gentlemen --
I hope I'm not interrupting.
What is it now, Dukat?
I found it.
Behold -- the key to victory.
I see you remain skeptical. You    won't for long.

Over the last few months, I've    immersed myself in the study of    the Bajoran Ancient Texts. And    I've come to realize that the    wormhole is much more than just    a gateway to the Gamma Quadrant.    It's the Temple of the Prophets.    It's from there that they smile    benevolently down on Bajor.    It's from there that they    protect that world and its    people.        The sad truth is, we wasted our    time fighting the Bajorans when    we should've been fighting their    gods.
How do you fight a god?
I'll show you. You see, we have    an ally we never knew we had.         You may want to take a few steps back.
Dorrah tolka bretri pah'rahn,    meedor. Dorrah tolka ullkess    pah'rahn.
Dukat --
Your concern is touching, but    unnecessary.
Busy?
A little.
I'll be leaving with the task    force first thing in the    morning.
I heard.
And... ?
And I'm sorry I arrested him. I    was simply trying to do my duty,    but I can see how it might've    seemed excessive...
What are you talking about?
Vedek Solis. Isn't that why   you're here?
No, but now I know why you've    been avoiding me these last few    days.
I haven't been avoiding you.    I've been helping you avoid me.
Why would I want to do that?
Because... you don't want us to    be together anymore?
Is that what you've been    thinking? Odo -- we had an    argument. People have them all    the time. Look at Worf and Dax --    they love each other and they    fight all the time.
Are you saying you love me?
Don't try to change the subject.
Which is?
I don't even know anymore.
But you're no longer angry at    me?
That's right. Though I still    think you were wrong to arrest    the Vedek.
I see.
And I thought it'd be nice if we    spent my last night on the    station together.
That's a wonderful idea.
Then I'll see you later.
I look forward to it.
Good.
You know, Nerys, observing    humanoid relationships and being    in one are very different    things.
If you ask me, it's an ungodly    hour to go to war.         And you can quote me on that.
I will.
Do me a favor, Jadzia. Look in    on Keiko and the kids while I'm    gone.
You can count on it.
And make sure Julian stays out   of trouble.
Now you're pushing...
It's your station, old man.
I'll take good care of her.
Give my best to the Jem'Hadar.
I'll do that.    (looking to Worf and    Dax)   I said a prayer for the two of   you at the shrine last night.
About having a baby?
Sometimes the Prophets can be   helpful in these matters.
I hope they were listening.
You hear that? We have the    Prophets on our side.
According to Doctor Bashir, we    could use all the help we can    get.
Just remember, when you get    back, we have a lot of "work" to    do.
I do not consider that "work."
I wish I was going with you.
You are.        In here.
I love it when you get romantic.
You got here early.
This is a momentous occasion.    It's not every day I embark on a    journey to liberate my    homeworld.
That's one way to put it.
This is General Martok to all    ships. Assume tactical    formation, we're moving out.
Take us to Cardassia, Mister Nog.
Aye, sir.
The enemy fleet is approaching    the Chin'toka System.
What's the status of our weapon    platforms?
Still off-line.
It pains me to say this, but you    Cardassians are proving to be    quite a disappointment.
(surprisingly    confident)   I'll remind you you said that.
Looks like we're in luck,    captain. The defensive grid's    still off-line.
Jem'Hadar fighters approaching,    bearing zero-five-nine mark zero-   three-one.
They must know they don't stand    a chance against a fleet this    size.
That won't matter to the    Jem'Hadar.
Sit down, Jake.
Right.
Martok to Sisko.
Go ahead.
My attack wing is closest to    those Jem'Hadar fighters. We're    preparing to engage them.
Good luck, general.
I always knew the Jem'Hadar were    crazy.
There's method to their madness.    They're inflicting considerable    damage on the Klingons.
And buying time to get their    Weapon Platforms operational.
Sisko to Martok.
The Jem'Hadar have managed to    cripple or destroy fifteen of my    ships.
Do you need assistance?
No, that won't be necessary.    Commence firing on the Weapon    Platforms.
I believe you owe me an apology.
(in a much better     mood)    I believe you're right.
Now if Dukat can get our    reinforcements through the    wormhole...
I'm not sure how much faith I    have in this -- what did he call    it?
A Pah-wraith.
Pah-wraiths and Prophets. All    this talk of gods strikes me as    nothing more than superstitious    nonsense.
You believe that the Founders   are gods, don't you?
That's different.
In what way?
The Founders are gods.
We're unable to penetrate their   forcefields.
Chief -- isolate their lower    frequency shield harmonics.    Find a way to punch through.
Their resonance modulations are    fluctuating at an exponential    rate. It'll take time to find a    pattern we can lock onto.
We don't have time.
Captain, I just noticed    something odd about those    platforms.
Don't keep it to yourself,    Mister Garak.
None of them seem to have a    power generator on board.
He's right. Each one must be    getting its power from a central    source.
We've got to find that source    and destroy it.
Chief --
I'm on it.
According to the DNA scans I    took this morning, the ovarian    resequencing enzymes I've given    you are working.
You mean Worf and I can have a    baby?
It looks that way.         I have to say, I didn't expect    such positive results so    quickly. It's quite amazing,    actually.
Thank you, Julian.
It's all part of being a doctor.
No, it's more than that. You're    a good friend. You always have    been.
(with genuine     gallantry)    And I always will be.
I'd better get back to work...        But first, I think I'll stop by    the Bajoran shrine.
What for?
Kira said a prayer for Worf and    me last night. She told the    Prophets how much we wanted a    baby.
Then I'd say they were listening   -- that is, if you believe in    Prophets.
I do today.
I'm not sure if I'm doing this    correctly... I don't come here a    lot.

To be honest, I'm more   comfortable thinking of you as   wormhole aliens. But Kira   believes you're a lot more than   that...        Maybe she's right, I don't know.    But if you are prophets, and    you're listening to me right    now... I just want to say --
Dukat?
Captain --
Dad, what is it?
I'm not sure... I think I felt    the Prophets reaching out to me.       Something's wrong...
Sir, I found it. There's a    subspace power generator on a    small moon orbiting the far    planet. It's transmitting    energy to the weapon platforms.
Captain?
Take us there, Mister Nog.
Aye, sir.
You better get him to his    quarters.
Don't worry, captain. We'll get    the job done.
I know this must be of little    comfort, but I never intended    you any harm.
On screen.
Target locked.
Fire.
We can't penetrate the moon's    defense grid.
Sir, I have an idea.
Go ahead.
Maybe we can't destroy that    power generator, but I'd bet    those Weapon Platforms could.
Why would they fire on their own    power source?
We'd have to fool the platforms'    targeting systems into thinking    the generator is an enemy ship.
We can use our deflector array    to imprint a Federation warp    signature on the generator's    energy matrix.
It's worth a try.
Evasive maneuvers, Mister Nog.    Pattern Theta.
Induction stabilizers set.    Booster modulators synchronized.    Ready to activate the deflector.
Do it.
Martok to the Defiant.
Go ahead, General.
Well done, major. We'll begin    transporting ground troops to    both planets immediately.
Major, we're getting a priority-   one transmission from Deep Space    Nine.       It's from Julian.
This is a disaster! Federation   soldiers have landed on   Cardassian soil. And now you're   telling me the wormhole is gone!
And with it any chance of our   getting reinforcements from the   Gamma Quadrant.
I'm well aware that things    didn't turn out quite the way    I'd planned, but I assure you    we've still achieved a great    victory.
Forgive me if I don't share your    euphoria.
But you should. The Bajoran    people have been cut off from    their gods... perhaps forever.
And how does that help us?
Because Sisko's been cut off    from the Prophets as well. And    without the Prophets, he's just    another Starfleet captain.
And that's supposed to make me    feel better?
Believe me, it will.

Emissary! My mother says all    the orbs are dark -- that the    Prophets have abandoned us.    (not waiting for a     response)    You have to find them, Emissary.    You have to ask them to come    back.
I'll try.
I was able to save the Dax    symbiont, but we need to get it    back to Trill as soon as    possible.        There was nothing I could do for    Jadzia.
Are you all right, Captain?
I've been better...
I'm sorry...
Save your strength.
Our baby... would've been so    beautiful.

neH taH Kronos. Hegh bat'lhqu    Hoch nej maH. neH taH Kronos.    yay je bat'lh manob Hegh.   (Only Kronos endures. All we    can hope for is a glorious    death. Only Kronos endures. In    death there is victory and    honor.)
The funeral service is due to    begin in a few minutes,    Jadzia... but I need to talk to    you one last time.

When I first met you, you said    that my relationship with Jadzia    Dax wouldn't be any different    than the one I had with Curzon    Dax. But that's not the way    things worked out. I had a    helluva lot of fun with both of    you. But Curzon was my mentor.    You... you were my friend. And    I'm going to miss you.        I should've listened to the Prophets    and not gone to Cardassia... maybe    then you'd still be alive.        Why aren't you here, Jadzia? I    need you to help me sort things    out. Something's happened to    the Prophets... something that's    made them turn their backs on    Bajor, and I'm responsible. But    I don't know what to do about    it. How to make it right.        I've failed as the Emissary and,    for the first time in my life,    I've failed in my duty as a    Starfleet officer.        I need time to think... clear my    head. And I can't do it here.    Not on the station. Not now. I    have to get away... so I can    figure out a way to make things    right again.        I have to make things right,    Jadzia. I have to.
The station's all yours, major.
She'll be here when you get   back.
Sir, this leave of absence   you're taking... how long do you   think you'll be gone?
I can't say exactly.
We'll be waiting.
Best of luck, sir.
Thank you, Chief. My thanks to   all of you.
Let's go home, Jake.
Landing Pad "C."
I was afraid of that. He's not    sure he's coming back.
What makes you say that?
His baseball. He took it with    him.
Dad...
scene: 94   EXT. NEW ORLEANS - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: Grandpa's ready to close up the    restaurant. He wants to know    when you're coming in.
scene: 94   EXT. NEW ORLEANS - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: In a little while...
scene: 94   EXT. NEW ORLEANS - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT
